bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, April 10, 1876

div1.p: Reed awaits his new orders. His replacement has arrived.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, April 10, 1876
div1.p:
You must
excuse my pencil-writing, as I would
not resort to it, were it not for
the fact that every table & ink-
stand in the house is occupied,
at present, by busy scribes-
Seated at my own table & dipping
into my own inkstand, the newly
arrived Dr Cunningham is writing
away for dear life- He came
on Saturday last & relieves me
from duty at Willet's Point-
He is a Virginian - hails from
Danville - graduated at the Univ-
ersity of Va-in days gone by, &
has just entered the Army-
& is, as yet, not too learned in
his Profession-nor is he pretty-
but is probably a very good
young man. I was not glad
to see him, at all, inasmuch as
he relieves me from my present,
pleasant situation - to which
I find that I have become
very much attached- How
soon I will go, I do not,
as yet, know- my orders have
not arrived, but am expec-
ting them by every mail that
arrives- I hope that I will
be ordered to the South or to
some Post, from which I can
easily visit reach the little
town of Murfreesboro, at a
certain not very distant day
in the Future. Not but that
I would be willing to under-
go any amount of fatigue
in order to obtain your, darling
little self- Most truly I would -
but the easier & nearer, the quicker
would be the journey & you know
that I am jealous of every
hour that passes out of your Society.
(Just here I am interrupted &
called to see a sick woman-
Have returned & if not an-
noyed more than a dozen times
within an hour, I trust I shall
be able to finish my letter.)
Your very long and very sweet
letter came this morning & notwith-
standing & notwithstanding the
above mentioned qualities rec-
ommended it very strongly to
my favor, yet I am feel bound
to give you a good sharp scol-
ding, my little Emilie! How could
you, my love, have been so im-
prudent as to almost blind
yourself by reading so many
pages in so few hours, &, of course,
of the very finest type, as all
novels are- Why, precious, I am
literally speechless! If you
are going to act in this way,
I shall come & take you away
from such temptations, at once!
I don't want, my little darling to
become blind, but were such
to happen, you know, my pet,
or if you do not, I'll tell you
that I should still love you
just as much, aif not more, than
ever! I will never break the
chain that binds our hearts to-
gether for neither blindness, deaf-
ness nor dumbness! Excuse brevity
Delay your next letter, till you hear
from me again, and believe me,
div1.closer:
Ever, darling, your own fond &
devoted, Walter.
